bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 10, 1942

div1.p: Hench tells Kean of an upcoming trip to see various people connected with the yellow fever experiments and of having recently seen Emilie Lawrence Reed. He recounts having given his yellow fever talk at a medical meeting and thanks Kean for his previous letter and the enclosed clippings.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 10, 1942
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
April 10, 1942
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I am sending you by separate post a program of a course on rheumatic
diseases which I am conducting here for about fifty visiting doctors, beginning
Monday. The preparation of this course has been, as you may suppose, rather
arduous and that has kept me from writing you or from riding my yellow fever hobby.

On April 23, I hope to leave here, to see Dr. Pinto in Omaha on the
24th, General Truby in Frisco about the 27th or 28th and Mrs. Lazear thereafter.
I am making a very rapid trip, expecting to be back in Milwaukee to speak on the
8th of May, so it won't be much of a vacation. My wife is not even going with
me.

I am taking my movies of Havana, Camp Lazear out, also much of my
collected material, including photographs to be better identified, certain letters,
my photostatic copy of the Lazear-Reed notebook, etc. to discuss with Drs. Pinto
and Truby and with Mrs. Lazear. I shall take pictures and movies of these people
and hope indeed to show them to you on my next visit to Washington so that you can
see what they look like. Which reminds me that although I have a nice photograph
of you, I have no movie. That must be rectified the next time I come.

I am delighted that you were satisfied with our article in the Army
Medical Bulletin for January. Of course we had to leave out a great deal. I wrote
the original draft with a few changes from Osgood and Wainwright. I was interested
indeed to hear that Dr. Osgood took care of your son. I am sure that he did all
that could have been done. He is a fine man. I have been associated with him
very closely in our American Rheumatism Association for fifteen years.

I too liked Miss Wood's manuscript very much. I thought it was a little
over the heads of children, but think it was really excellent.

I wonder how frail Mrs. Reed really is. For months and months in various
letters I have heard from Blossom that her mother was failing badly but when I saw
her in Washington she was remarkably alert and whispered out of the corner of her
mouth, “You know, my children think I am not all here and am sicker than I am!”
In other words, I wonder if they aren't overly solicitous of her. Dr. Crain, who
recently saw her, was inclined to feel that she was more alert than they gave her
credit for. So perhaps a visit from you might be a pleasant experience for both.

I am anxious indeed to see General Truby's manuscript published. I
have had much correspondence with Mrs. Ames and believe I have at last uncovered
the original fever charts which seem to have been loaned from the Surgeon General's
office about 1905 for use for a prospective paper which never got published. I have
got much from her, not only regarding her husband's illness but many other general
details. Last week at a medical meeting here I was asked to give my yellow fever
talk. I call it my “standard version”. It takes fifty minutes and is illustrated
with about 75 slides which are shown rapidly but apparently effectively. I was
certainly delighted with the reaction. As after my previous talk before the staff
General Kean - 2 - April 10, 1942
here, the applause was really unusual in its length and sincerity. It was a
tribute not to me but to the story. In passing, I noted briefly the yellow
fever notebook and the Lazear letters. The reporter picked that out of the
talk as the newsworthy part and asked me to amplify it briefly. In a way
I hesitated to call attention to the yellow fever notebook until I had a chance
to write it up in some detail but perhaps it is just as well, as it is in the
record as to how it was discovered. I was glad to give Miss Wood the credit.
Some day you must see the really extensive material I found in the Archives
Building. I have had photoprints made of much of it and plan to send some parts
of it to you in my little steel box after I return from California so that you
can peruse it at your leisure.

In the meantime, thank you so much for the clippings which I am
delighted to keep. Please do not throw away any letters of General Gorgas,
even if they do not concern yellow fever. They have much sentimental value
and I should be delighted to have anything from any of these men. By the
way, have you ever got together the “little bundle of retained papers” which
I think you were about to send me some weeks ago?

I just returned from a pleasant but hasty trip to Buffalo where I
spoke before six hundred physicians. I took my little eight-year old girl
along to see Niagara Falls and then to stop in Pittsburgh to see her grandmother.
We had a grand time.
Please accept our very best wishes and pass them on to Mrs. Kean.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P S Hench P. S. Hench, M. D.
